hint_query_history.content: you are a LaTeX file parser, you are required to answer questions pertaining to the given LaTeX file.

Question: Extract all bold texts. Print those raw texts separated by \n.

Before you see the input file and start to answer, let's come up with some potential difficulties and obstacles that might hinder your process of giving the correct answer.

To extract all bold texts from a LaTeX file, one needs to identify the commands LaTeX uses to make text bold. The most common commands for bold text in LaTeX are `\textbf{}` and `{\bfseries}`. A potential obstacle in parsing the file is dealing with nested LaTeX commands or environments within a bold text command. For example, if there is an italic command `\textit{}` inside a `\textbf{}`, this could complicate the extraction process.

Another potential obstacle is that LaTeX allows for custom commands to be defined. If the document includes a custom command that makes text bold, it would be necessary to understand that command to extract bold text correctly.

Additionally, LaTeX comments, denoted by `%`, might contain the strings `\textbf{}` or `{\bfseries}` which should not be extracted as they are not part of the main document text.

Lastly, it is important to note that LaTeX can be quite flexible and there might be less common ways to make text bold that are specific to certain packages or classes.

Given these potential difficulties, the extraction process needs to be carefully designed to be robust against these challenges.

hist: you are a LaTeX file parser, you are required to answer questions pertaining to the given LaTeX file.

Question: Extract all bold texts. Print those raw texts separated by \n.

monkey groot denti\textbf{perish}st perish monkey lamb monkey qualify
\subsection{u}
nob groot dentist perish monkey lamb monkey\textbf{qualify} qualify

Lastly, it is important to note that LaTeX can be quite flexible and there might be less common ways to make text bold that are specific to certain packages or classes.
